Graphical abstract The purpose of this study was to clarify the effect of a transition metal (Mn, Fe, Co) substitution in the BaZrO3 catalyst on the performance of ethylbenzene dehydrogenation (EBDH) with steam. The BaZrO3 catalyst showed a high performance for the EBDH without steam, however the co-feeding of steam produced a significant decrease in the EBDH activity. By partially substituting the Zr site in the BaZrO3 catalyst with Mn or Fe, the dehydrogenation activity was dramatically improved, while the Co-substituted catalyst showed a significantly low activity. In particular, the Fe substitution of a small percentage from 2 to 4% was effective for the drastic enhancement of the EBDH performance with steam. Comparing the styrene yield over the BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst with that over the industrial potassium-promoted iron oxide (Fe–K) catalyst, the BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst produced a higher styrene yield than the Fe–K catalyst. From the ESR measurement, we found that the Fe-substituted BZO catalyst had the defect–dipole (Fe3+–V ox) in its structure after EBDH with steam. Highly-active BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst had a large amount of the defect–dipole and therefore an increase of the oxygen mobility. On the other hand, although low-active catalyst had a large amount of the defect–dipole, but the non-uniformity in the environment of the defect–dipole was increased. Such differences might cause a redox property and a performance for EBDH with steam. The drastic change in activity and environment around the oxygen defect by a small amount of Fe substitution is reported for the first time in the field of perovskite catalysts. Keywords Dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene Perovskite oxide catalyst BaZrO3 Fe-substitution 1 Introduction Styrene, used for polymeric materials such as polystyrene resin, acrylonitrile–butadiene–styrene resin, and styrene–butadiene rubber, is an important monomer associated with petro-chemistry. Styrene production volume is about 30 million tons annually, more than 90% of which is produced by dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene (EBDH), as expressed in the following chemical Eq. (1) [1,2]. (1) C8H10 ⇄C8H8 +H2 ΔH 298 =124kJmol−1 EBDH is an endothermic reaction. Therefore, high temperatures are necessary for high ethylbenzene conversion because of its thermodynamic limitation. The catalyst of Fe–K, an often-used industrial catalyst [3], contains promoters such as Cr2O3 [3–5], CeO2, MoO3 [6,7], and Pd [8]. Even now, a great deal of research has been conducted for the improvement of the catalyst. Generally, radial-type adiabatic reactors have been applied in commercial processes for EBDH [9]. Superheated steam as a heating source is supplied to the catalyst bed with ethylbenzene to control the reaction temperature. Steam also acts as a diluent for shifting the equilibrium conversion higher, and suppresses over-reduction of the Fe–K catalyst in the reductive atmosphere. Additionally, steam suppresses carbon deposition on the surface of the Fe–K catalyst [10,11]. However, the present industrial process is very energy consuming due to the required excess of superheated steam and higher reaction temperatures. Therefore development of a catalyst that can work under low steam conditions and at low temperatures has been pursued. In the previous study, we investigated the reaction mechanism of ethylbenzene dehydrogenation in the presence of H2O on an industrial Fe–K catalyst using periodic pulse experiments with a mass spectrometer [12]. The reaction mechanism over the Fe–K was redox-type; ethylbenzene was oxidized to styrene using lattice oxygen (Eq. (2)) and the produced oxygen vacancy was regenerated with steam (Eq. (3)). (2) C8H10 +O2− lat →C8H8 +H2O+ V ox +2e− (3) H2O+ V ox +2e− →H2 +O2− lat where, O2− lat and V ox denote the lattice oxygen and lattice vacancy in the Fe–K catalyst. In other words, the catalytic activity and stability depended on redox characteristics of the lattice oxygen in the catalyst. Perovskite-type mixed oxides (general formula is ABO3, A is a rare-earth or an alkali-earth element and B is typically a transition metal) have a high mobility of lattice oxygen in comparison to some common transition metal oxides. The redox ability of the perovskite materials could be controlled by the incorporation of a variety of elements [13–16]. In addition, perovskite-type mixed oxides have a much better thermal stability than transition metal oxides, and their catalytic activities are sometimes competitive with the supported noble metal catalysts [17]. Based on these properties, perovskite-type oxides is considered to be suitable for EBDH in order to acquire a high activity. From the screening for the dehydrogenation catalyst, the La0.8Ba0.2Fe0.4Mn0.6O3− δ (abbreviated as LBFMO) perovskite catalyst was found to show a high activity and stability for EBDH in our recent study [18]. The reaction mechanism over the LBFMO was redox-type; ethylbenzene was oxidized to styrene using lattice oxygen (Eq. (2)) and the produced oxygen vacancy was regenerated with steam (Eq. (3)). The role of Mn in the LBFMO was to release the lattice oxygen and that of Fe was to replenish the lattice oxygen [19,20]. The high stable activity was found to be derived from the well-balanced redox reaction of Eqs. (2) and (3). By incorporating the low-valence metal ion such as Ba2+, Sr2+, or Ca2+ in A-site in the structure, oxygen vacancies were produced for keeping the charge neutralization condition, and it would bring high oxygen ionic conductivity. Especially, the incorporation of elements with a large ionic radii, such as Ba, into the A-site of the perovskite structure produces a high free volume in the lattice, which decreases the activation energy of the oxygen ion migration [21,22] In case of substituting the A-site cations with high-valence metal cations, the perovskite structure stability increases, although the ionic conductivity decreases due to the reduction of the amount of oxygen vacancies [23]. When a partial substitution of the A-site with the same-valence cations might improve the structure stability with keeping the oxygen mobility at the same level [24,25]. To further promote redox property, one of the effective approaches is the B-site substitution in the perovskite-type oxide. Teraoka investigated the rate of oxygen permeation through La1−x Sr x Co1−y Fe y O3−δ [26]. The Co3+ cations have a smaller ionic radius as well as smaller bonding energy to oxide ions in comparison with Fe, and Mn, which was resulted in the descending permeability order as follows: Co>Fe>Mn. They also mentioned the importance of the ABO3 perovskite-type structure for high oxygen mobility. The highest dopant concentration produces the highest oxygen flux, as long as preserve the perovskite structure. Ba-based perovskite materials that are expected to show high activity for EBDH due to good redox properties as mentioned above. In the recent work, the BaZrO3 (abbreviated as BZO) perovskite-type oxide catalyst exhibited a superior styrene yield to the Fe–K catalyst which is well known for high activity for EBDH [27]. To enhance the dehydrogenation property of the BZO catalyst, we performed a partial substitution of the B-site with transition metals of the Mn, Fe and Co cations. In the present study, the catalytic performance of the BZO catalyst was found to be drastically improved by substituting with a small amount of Fe cations. To discuss about the promotional effect, we performed some characterizations of the catalyst before and after the reaction; the morphological change in the catalyst crystal was examined by a scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM), and the presence of oxygen vacancies was investigated by electron spin resonance (ESR). 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Some perovskite oxides, such as a BaZrO3, BaB0.02Zr0.98O3 (B: Mn, Fe, Co), BaFe y Zr1−y O3 (0≤ y ≤0.2) and AFe0.02B’0.98O3 (A: Ca, Sr, Ba; B’: Zr, Ti), were prepared by the conventional solid state reaction. The preparation procedure is described with an example of the BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst. Firstly, BaCO3 and ZrO2 and a Fe2O3 were weighed to be the molar ratio of Ba/Zr/Fe=1.00/0.98/0.02. These powders were thoroughly mixed in an agate mortar, pelletized, then calcined at 1473K for 12h. In case of the preparation of the other substituted catalysts, carbonate and metal oxides were used as reagents. The industrial potassium-promoted iron oxide (G-84C, made by Nissan Girdler K.K.; composition=77wt%–Fe2O3, 10wt%–K2O, 5.0wt%–Ce2O3, 2.5wt%–MoO3, 2.2wt%–CaO, 2.2wt%–MgO, and less than 0.1wt%–of Cr2O3) catalyst was used as the reference catalyst. 2.2 Activity test The catalytic activity, selectivity and stability of the prepared catalyst for the EBDH were examined in using a conventional fixed bed reactor. The reactor used for this study was comprised of a quartz tube (10-mm o.d.) containing a catalyst bed, which was fixed by quartz wool. A type-K thermocouple for controlling the temperature was positioned outside the quartz tube. The reactions were conducted at 823K under atmospheric pressure in the presence of steam; the molar ratio of steam to ethylbenzene was 0, 1 or 6. The EB of 1.2gh−1 was supplied to the catalyst bed diluted by helium (P EB: 6.3kPa). The catalyst weight was 0.2 or 0.5g. Liquid products, such as ethylbenzene, benzene, toluene, and styrene, were analyzed using an off-line thermal conductivity detection (TCD) gas chromatograph (GC-8A; Shimadzu Co., Ltd., Japan). The conversion (Eq. (4)), styrene yield (Eq. (5)) and selectivity to styrene (Eq. (6)) were evaluated using the following equations. (4) EB conversion = [ Sty ] + [ Bz ] + [ Tol ] [ EB ] + [ Sty ] + [ Bz ] + [ Tol ] × 100 (5) Styrene yield = [ Sty ] [ Sty ] + [ Bz ] + [ Tol ] × EB conversion (6) Styrene selectivity = [ Sty ] [ Sty ] + [ Bz ] + [ Tol ] × 100 The [EB], [Sty], [Bz], and [Tol] denote the concentration of EB, styrene, benzene and toluene in the effluent gas, respectively. Carbon balances in this study were calculated from the basis on the aromatics molecules. The mass balance was obtained at almost 100% for all the experimentally obtained results. 2.3 Characterization The crystalline structure of the prepared catalyst was ascertained by X-ray powder diffraction with Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.54Å, Rint-2000; Rigaku Co., Ltd., Japan). The specific surface area of the perovskite oxide was analyzed by a N2 absorption method (Model 4200; Nikkiso Co., Ltd., Japan). The sample was outgassed at 423K for 30min before the N2 adsorption. In order to study the distribution of Fe in the substituted catalyst and to observe its surface morphology, the STEM images and EDX mappings were obtained using a HD-2300A/EDAX (Hitachi Co., Ltd., Japan) with an accelerating voltage of 200kV. The electron spin resonance (abbreviated ESR) spectra were obtained using an EMX spectrometer (Bruker BioSpin Corp.) at a field modulation of 100kHz, an amplitude modulation of 0.8mT and a microwave power of 0.02mW. The measurement was performed at room temperature in ambient air without vacuum-pumping. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of steam on the performance over the BaZrO3 catalyst The dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene (denoted as EBDH) with or without steam was carried out over the BaZrO3 (abbreviated BZO) catalyst for investigating the effect of steam on the catalytic performance. The obtained result is shown in Fig. 1 . The reaction temperature was 823K. The feed rate of EB was 1.2gh−1, the steam/EB ratio was 0 or 1, and the catalyst weight was 0.2g. Under the no-steam flow condition (EB only), the BZO catalyst without any H2 pre-reduction before the dehydrogenation showed an induction period of about 15min. The maximum styrene yield was 34.4% with a 98.8% styrene selectivity. The activity passed through a maximum with time, followed by a deactivation from 34.4% to 30.6% during 15min. The slow deactivation was considered to be derived from the coke on the catalyst because of no steam condition. On the other hand, the prereduced BZO catalyst, which was reduced by H2 with a flow rate of 100mlmin−1 (10vol% H2 balanced by He) for 1h, showed a high activity without the induction period; the initial styrene yield was 32.5% with a 98.4% styrene selectivity. The initial high activity was derived from the creation of adsorption sites of ethylbenzene by the H2 reduction [20]. The EB, which has a soft basic aromaticity, was chemisorbed on the acidic Zr sites on the catalyst surfaces. Without pre-reduction, the outermost surface layer of the as-made BZO catalyst consisted of lattice oxygen. Hence, no chemical interaction of EB occurred on the oxygen terminated BZO surface due to the repulsive electrostatic interaction between the surface lattice oxygen and the π orbital in EB. As for the BZO catalyst with pre-reduction, the surface lattice oxygen was removed by the H2, and the Zr cation as the acidic site was then exposed on the catalyst surface. Therefore, the soft basic aromatic molecule of EB chemisorbed on the Zr site produced by H2 reduction, which produced the initial high activity over the BZO catalyst. In the presence of steam as shown in Fig. 1, the catalytic activity was significantly low even if the H2 reduction was done before the reaction. The initial styrene yields over the untreated BZO and the prereduced BZO were 2.6% with 89.2% styrene selectivity and 3.2% with 88.1% styrene selectivity, respectively. The low activity in the presence of steam might be derived from the dissociative adsorption of water on the reactive site. Graf et al. investigated the reactivity of water on the Pt/ZrO2 catalyst by in-situ transmission FT-IR [28]. They mentioned that the water dissociation occurred on the catalyst and a mono-coordinated OH-group was created on a defective Zr3+-cation. Therefore, if the Zr cation as the acidic site was exposed on the catalyst surface, the OH-group might be created on its site. The significant loss of activity by steam was probably due to covering the surface reactive site by steam. 3.2 Effect of B-site substitution by Mn, Fe and Co on dehydrogenation activity Based on the previous Section 3.1, it was found that the coexistence of steam in the feeding material caused deactivation of the BZO catalyst for the EBDH. The co-feeding of steam in the industrial EBDH process has an important role such as providing heat to the endothermic dehydrogenation, diluting EB in order to increase the equilibrium conversion, and to prevent coke deposition on the catalyst. In terms of an industrial application of the BZO catalyst, the catalyst must work in the presence of steam. Hence, a partial substitution of the B-site (=Zr) by a transition metal, such as Mn, Fe and Co cations, was performed to improve the performance of the BZO catalyst. Fig. 2 shows the dehydrogenation performance in the presence of steam over the BZO and the BaB’0.02Zr0.98O3 (B’:Mn, Fe, Co) catalysts. The reaction condition was as follows: the feed rate of EB was 1.2gh−1, the steam/EB ratio was 6, and the catalyst weight was 0.2g. The value in parentheses in Fig. 2 is the specific surface area of these catalysts. The styrene yields over these catalysts were as follows: 2.3% yield over the BZO catalyst; 9.0% yield over the BaMn0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst; 28.9% yield over the BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst; 1.7% yield over the BaCo0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst. Surprisingly, the Mn- and Fe-substituted catalysts produced a high dehydrogenation activity even when the steam was simultaneously present with EB. Especially, the BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst was highly active. On the other hand, the Co-substituted catalyst showed a low specific surface area, which might produce a low activity. As for the selectivity for styrene, the selectivity did not decline with the Fe-substitution. The BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst showed a 97.2% high styrene selectivity. An additional experiment was undertaken with the objective of investigating the optimum Fe substitution ratio in the BaFe y Zr1−y O3 (0≤ y ≤0.2) catalysts. First, we investigated the effect of the Fe substitution in the BZO catalyst on the structure and specific surface area (abbreviated S.S.A.) of these catalysts. Fig. 3 shows XRD patterns of the BaFe y Zr1−y O3 (0≤ y ≤0.2) catalysts. From the XRD pattern, the peak shift was not clearly observed over BaFe y Zr1−y O3 (0.05≤ y ≤0.2) catalyst, compared to the BZO catalyst. The impurity phases were not observed over the BaFe y Zr1−y O3 catalysts, except for the BaFe0.2Zr0.8O3 catalyst. Over the BaFe0.2Zr0.8O3 catalyst, a slight impurity phase was observed. Table 1 shows the S.S.A. of these catalysts. From Table 1, the S.S.A. slightly decreased by the Fe substitution compared to the bare BZO catalyst. In particular, the surface area was reduced to a comparatively low value by 20% Fe substitution. Fig. 4 shows the styrene yield and selectivity for styrene at the steady-state of the 2h reaction. The reaction condition was as follows: the feed rate of EB was 1.2gh−1, the steam/EB ratio was 6, and the catalyst weight was 0.2g. The Fe–K industrial catalyst (G-84C, made by Nissan Girdler K.K.) was utilized as the reference. From Fig. 4, it was found that the Fe substitution was effective for enhancement of the dehydrogenation activity at a low Fe substitution. The styrene yield increased from a 2.8% yield over the bare BZO catalyst to a 28.9% yield over the 2%-Fe substituted catalyst. However, when the 20% Fe substitution was performed, the styrene yield decreased to 2.0%. Namely, the optimum Fe substitution was a low percentage from 2 to 4%. The relation between the S.S.A. and dehydrogenation activity was not clearly confirmed. The B-site synergistic effect is likely to occur by several tens of percent substitution in the perovskite catalysts as shown in the introduction [11–13,17]. Such a drastic enhancement by a small amount of Fe substitution is reported for the first time for the perovskite catalyst. Comparing the styrene yield over the BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst with that over the industrial potassium-promoted iron oxide (Fe–K) catalyst, the BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst was found to provide a higher styrene yield than the Fe–K catalyst during 2h reaction. The selectivity to styrene did not significantly change even if the Fe substitution was performed in the BZO catalyst. In other words, the reactive site was considered not to change by the substitution. In order to evaluate whether or not the activity enhancement by the Fe substitution was only over the BZO catalyst, the catalytic activity tests were carried out over the AFe0.02Zr0.98O3 (A:Ca and Sr) and A’Fe0.02Ti0.98O3 (A’:Ca, Sr and Ba) catalysts as well as the AZrO3 and A’TiO3 catalysts. The reaction condition was as follows: the feed rate of EB was 1.2gh−1, the steam/EB ratio was 6, and the catalyst weight was 0.5g. Fig. 5 shows the styrene yield at the steady-state over these catalysts. The specific surface area of these catalysts is shown in parenthesis in Fig. 5. By substituting Zr with Fe, a 25.6-fold higher activity was obtained over the SrFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst than that over the SrZrO3 catalyst; and a 3.0-fold higher activity over the CaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst than over the CaZrO3 catalyst. As for the Ti-based perovskites, a 3.3-fold higher yield was obtained over the BaFe0.02Ti0.98O3 catalyst than that over the BaTiO3 catalyst; and a 16.3-fold higher activity over the SrFe0.02Ti0.98O3 catalyst than over the SrTiO3 catalyst; and a 3.5-fold higher activity over the CaFe0.02Ti0.98O3 catalyst than over the CaTiO3 catalyst. Based on these results, the activity enhancement was observed not only over the Zr-based perovskite catalysts, but also over the Ti-based catalysts. Furthermore, the Fe substitution effect was found not to be due to the S.S.A. of the catalyst. The reason for improving the activity by the Fe substitution is considered in Sections 3.4 and 3.5. 3.3 Characterization of as-made and used BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalysts Based on the presented results, the BaFe y ’Zr1−y’O3 (0.02≤ y’≤0.04) was a good candidate catalyst for the EBDH in the presence of steam. For considering the structural stability under the dehydrogenation conditions, the structures of the as-made BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst and the catalyst after a 120-min reaction (abbreviated used catalyst) were investigated by XRD. Fig. 6 shows the XRD patterns of these catalysts. The result indicated that the used catalyst had a perovskite structure even after the dehydrogenation reaction. In addition, each peak of the used catalyst had not shifted compared to the as-made catalyst. The lattice constant of both catalysts was 4.192Å. These lattice constants agreed well with the value (4.193Å) reported by Yamazaki et al. [29]. Therefore, the BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst was found to have a high tolerance to a reducing atmosphere. The STEM-EDX analyses were performed to examine the surface morphology and the Fe distribution in the BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 perovskite structure. Fig. 7 (a) and (b) portray the STEM images of the as-made BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst, and Fig. 7(c) and (d) show the images of the catalyst after a 120-min reaction, respectively. Based on these images, the particle diameter of both catalysts was about 100nm. The morphology of the catalyst was not affected by the dehydrogenation atmosphere. Fig. 8 (a)–(c) shows the EDX mapping of Ba, Zr and Fe in the as-made BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst, respectively. Fig. 8(e)–(g) shows the EDX mapping of Ba, Zr and Fe in the used catalyst, respectively. These mappings corresponded to the STEM images as shown in Fig. 7(b) and (d). As shown in these mappings, each element was not aggregated, but uniformly distributed on the catalyst over the as-made and the used catalyst. There were no differences in the mapping between the as-made and the used catalysts. The Supporting information 1 shows atomic concentration of the fresh and used BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalysts calculated by XPS measurement. The result was approximately consistent with the results of EDX because no significant change in the atomic concentration before and after reaction. Hence, the BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst has the potential to be a stable catalyst for the EBDH in the presence of steam, since any collapse of the crystal structure or aggregation of the Fe cation did not occur on the catalyst. 3.4 Role of Fe cation in BZO catalyst The role of Fe in the highly-active and selective BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst was evaluated by the activity measurements of the EBDH without steam. Fig. 9 shows the styrene yield versus time over the BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst with and without pre-reduction by H2. The reaction condition was as follows: the feed rate of EB was 1.2gh−1, and the catalyst weight was 0.2g. The dehydrogenation was performed without steam in the feed material. Unlike the catalytic behavior of the BZO catalyst in which the induction period was observed as shown in Fig. 1, the BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst showed a high activity of 20.2% for the EBDH without steam during the initial stage of the reaction. When the BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst was prereduced by H2 at 823 or 873K, these catalysts revealed 19.9% or 18.0% activity, respectively. The initial activity over the BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst without pretreatment was almost the same as the activity over the catalyst with pretreatment. These results indicated that the oxygen vacancy was produced as soon as supplying EB on the BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst. The reactions as represented by Eqs. (2) and/or (7) might occur on the catalyst. (2) C8H10 +O2− lat →C8H8 +H2O+ V ox +2e− (7) H2 +O2− lat →H2O+ V ox +2e− The O2− lat and V ox denote the lattice oxygen and oxygen vacancy in the BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst, respectively. In a previous study, we proposed that the outermost lattice oxygen over the BZO was removed by H2, and the Zr cation as the acidic site for the adsorption site of EB was exposed on the catalyst surface [20]. The opened EB adsorption channel could produce a high activity for EBDH. By substituting Zr with Fe, the reduction property of the catalyst was promoted, which might open the adsorption site as soon as supplying EB. Hence, the effect of a small amount of the Fe cation was considered to promote the reduction of the catalyst. For confirming the formation of oxygen vacancies in the catalyst, the ESR measurement was conducted over the BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst. Fig. 10 (a) and (b) shows ESR spectra of the as-made and used BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalysts. Here, the “used catalyst” means the catalyst after EBDH with steam. Previously, we confirmed the ESR signal at g =2.004 for the BZO catalyst, which corresponded to the oxygen vacancy [20]. However, the ESR signal at g =2.004 over the BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst in Fig. 10(a) was overlapped with the signal of Fe3+ in the catalyst, which makes qualitative analysis of the oxygen vacancy difficult over the BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst. From Fig. 10(b), the very small signal at g ≅6.0 over the as-made catalyst was observed. The defect–dipole complex of the oxygen vacancy in the vicinity of Fe3+ was observed at g =5.957 [30]. The appearance of a small signal by the substitution of Fe for Zr in the BaFe y’Zr1−y’O3 catalyst may be explained as follows: the substitution of Zr4+ by the Fe3+ cation can be represented by the defect Reaction (8) in the Kröger–Vink notation [31]. (8) 1 2 Fe 2 O 3 + Z r Zr × + 1 2 O O x → F e ′ Zr + 1 2 V O .. + ZrO 2 where Z r Zr × is a Zr4+ cation in the B-site position, F e ′ Zr is a Fe3+ cation in a Zr lattice position, and O O x is an O2– lat and V O .. is the oxygen vacancy in a regular anion site, respectively. By substituting Zr4+ with Fe3+, the oxygen vacancy was created in order to maintain the electroneutral condition. Since an oxygen vacancy was produced in the vicinity of the Fe cation, the small signal was observed at g ≅6.0. However, the sharp signal over the used catalyst was observed at g ≅6.0, which meant the production of the oxygen vacancy and the formation of the defect–dipole of F e ′ Zr − V O .. in the catalyst during the dehydrogenation. Such a creation of the reducing state in the BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst might produce a high performance for the EBDH in the presence of steam. The surface lattice oxygen was reduced by H2, and the Zr cation as the acidic site was then exposed on the catalyst surface. The production of the oxygen vacancy opened the EB adsorption channel. The opened EB adsorption channel could provide the high activity for the EBDH. 3.5 Defect–dipole in BaFe y Zr1−y O3 (0≤ y ≤0.2) In terms of the styrene yield, the optimum Fe substitution ratio was from 2 to 4%. For investigating the reason for the optimum Fe substitution ratio, the ESR measurements were conducted over the BaFe y Zr1−y O3 (0≤ y ≤0.2) catalysts after the EBDH with steam. The ESR spectra at about g ≅6.0 are shown in Fig. 11 . As shown in this Fig. 11, the BaFe y ’Zr1−y’O3 (0.005≤ y’≤0.02) catalysts had the peak at g =5.98, which corresponded to the defect–dipole of F e ′ Zr − V O .. [30]. Additionally, the peak intensity and its area increased with the increase in the Fe substitution ratio. The order of the peak intensity and its peak area agreed with the catalytic activity over the BaFe y ’Zr1−y’O3 (0.005≤ y’≤0.02) catalyst, except for the BaFe0.1Zr0.9O3 and BaFe0.2Zr0.8O3 catalyst. The differences in the ESR spectra were the peak position and shape of the peak. Comparing the peak position of the BaFe y’Zr1−y’O3 (0.005≤ y’≤0.02) catalysts with the BaFe0.1Zr0.9O3 catalyst, the peak shifted to a higher g-factor, where the peak was observed at 6.04. In addition, its peak was broadened although the peak shape of the BaFe y’Zr1−y’O3 (0.005≤ y’≤0.02) catalysts was sharp. Also, over the BaFe0.2Zr0.8O3 catalyst, the peak was further shifted to a higher g-factor and broadened. This behavior is thought to be due to the different environment of the defect–dipole in the BaFe y Zr1−y O3 catalyst. For the low Fe substitution ratio, such as 0.5% to 2%, the defect dipole of F e ′ Zr − V O .. was surrounded by the Zr cation. Namely, the structure, such as F e ′ Zr − V O .. − Z r Zr × , was present in the perovskite-type oxide. On the other hand, over the BaFe0.1Zr0.9O3 and BaFe0.2Zr0.8O3 catalysts, the high Fe substitution ratio might produce the oxygen vacancy which was surrounded only by Fe cations. In other words, F e ′ Zr − V O .. − F e ′ Zr might be present in the high Fe-substituted catalyst. Such a different environment of the defect would produce the different shape of the peak and peak shift. Based on these results, the change in the catalytic activity was considered to be derived from the increase in the number of F e ′ Zr − V O .. for the defect dipole complex in the catalyst. This observation is similar to a recent study by Kovacevic et al. reporting on the relation between the reactivity of the CeZrO x catalyst for the EBDH with CO2 and the oxygen vacancy in the catalyst [32]. They found that the increase in the number of oxygen vacancies produced a high activity for the EBDH with CO2. In general, the lattice oxygen is more releasable by producing more oxygen vacancies in the catalyst. Namely, the production of the oxygen vacancy produces a high lattice oxygen mobility, which would provide a high activity for the EBDH via redox Reactions (2) and (3). (2) C8H10 +O2− lat →C8H8 +H2O+ V ox +2e− (3) H2O+ V ox +2e− →H2 +O2− lat On the other hand, in the high Fe substituted catalyst, such as the BaFe0.1Zr0.9O3 and BaFe0.2Zr0.8O3 catalysts, the low activity might be derived from F e ′ Zr − V O .. − F e ′ Zr of the oxygen vacancy bonded by the two trivalent Fe cations. Merkle and Maier mentioned that the iron-oxygen vacancy defect dipole complex would be rather immobile in the ceramic, compared to the ionic mobility of the free oxygen vacancy [33]. Its effect lowered the mobility of the lattice oxygen, which might produce a low activity. Thereby, the optimum Fe substitution was 0.005≤ y’≤0.02 in the BaFe y’Zr1−y’O3 catalyst. 4 Conclusions The Fe substitution in the BZO catalyst was effective for a good activity for the EBDH with steam. Especially, the BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst produced a high activity for the EBDH in the presence of steam, although the co-feeding of steam lead to a significant loss of its catalytic activity over the BZO catalyst. The ratio from a 2%- to 4%-Fe substitution drastically improved the catalytic performance. So far, little is known about the drastic enhancement of the catalytic performance by a small amount of substitution in the field of the perovskite catalyst. From the ESR measurement, the Fe-substitution in BZO catalyst brought a defect–dipole (Fe3+–V ox) in its structure. Highly-active BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst had a large amount of the defect–dipole in the structure. On the other hand, low-active catalyst also had a large amount of the defect–dipole, but the non-uniformity in the environment of the defect–dipole was increased. Such differences might produce a difference in redox property and a performance for EBDH with steam. coredata.dc:description: The purpose of this study was to clarify the effect of a transition metal (Mn, Fe, Co) substitution in the BaZrO3 catalyst on the performance of ethylbenzene dehydrogenation (EBDH) with steam. The BaZrO3 catalyst showed a high performance for the EBDH without steam, however the co-feeding of steam produced a significant decrease in the EBDH activity. By partially substituting the Zr site in the BaZrO3 catalyst with Mn or Fe, the dehydrogenation activity was dramatically improved, while the Co-substituted catalyst showed a significantly low activity. In particular, the Fe substitution of a small percentage from 2 to 4% was effective for the drastic enhancement of the EBDH performance with steam. Comparing the styrene yield over the BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst with that over the industrial potassium-promoted iron oxide (Fe–K) catalyst, the BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst produced a higher styrene yield than the Fe–K catalyst. From the ESR measurement, we found that the Fe-substituted BZO catalyst had the defect–dipole (Fe3+–V ox) in its structure after EBDH with steam. Highly-active BaFe0.02Zr0.98O3 catalyst had a large amount of the defect–dipole and therefore an increase of the oxygen mobility. On the other hand, although low-active catalyst had a large amount of the defect–dipole, but the non-uniformity in the environment of the defect–dipole was increased. Such differences might cause a redox property and a performance for EBDH with steam. The drastic change in activity and environment around the oxygen defect by a small amount of Fe substitution is reported for the first time in the field of perovskite catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Enhancement of ethylbenzene dehydrogenation of perovskite-type BaZrO3 catalyst by a small amount of Fe substitution in the B-site
